text.front:
DOI: 10.1002/zaac.200700461
Direct Syntheses of Bis(tetraphenylphosphonium) and
Bis(ethyltriphenylphosphonium) Hexabromo-diselenates(II), [PPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] and
[PEtPh 3 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ]. The Crystal Structure of [PEtPh 3 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ]
Vitalijus Janickis* ,a , Max Herberhold b and Wolfgang Milius b
a Kaunas/Lithuania , Faculty of Chemical Technology, Kaunas University of Technology
b Bayreuth/Germany, Laboratory of Inorganic Chemistry, University of Bayreuth
Received September 21 st , 2007; accepted December 4 th , 2007.
Abstract. Brown crystals of [PPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] (1) and
[PEtPh 3 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] (2) were obtained when selenium and bromine
reacted in acetonitrile solution in the presence of tetraphenylphos-
phonium bromide and ethyltriphenylphosphonium bromide,
respectively. The crystal structure of 2 has been determined by X-
ray methods and refined to R ϭ 0.0420 for 4161 reflections. The
crystals are monoclinic, space group P2 1 /n with Z ϭ 2 and a ϭ
13.055(3) Å , b ϭ 12.628(3) Å , c ϭ 13.530(3) Å , β ϭ 92.40(3)°(
293(2) K). In the solid state structure of 2 the dinuclear hexa-
text.body:
Introduction
The binary compound of selenium(II) with bromine, SeBr 2 ,
has not been isolated but gives a series of anionic complexes
with bromide ions. The known modifications of such com-
plexes are the nearly square-planar mononuclear [SeBr 4 ] 2Ϫ
ion [1, 2], the dinuclear [Se 2 Br 6 ] 2Ϫ ion formed by two edge-
sharing distorted SeBr 4 squares [1, 3], the trinuclear
[Se 3 Br 8 ] 2Ϫ ion consisting of three edge-sharing square-
planar SeBr 4 units [4], the tetranuclear ion [Se 4 Br 14 ] 2Ϫ
which is built of two parallel planar Se 2 Br 6 units connected
via two linear Br-bridges [4, 5], and the pentanuclear ion
[Se 5 Br 12 ] 2Ϫ , consisting of a central square-planar SeBr 4 unit
with two trans-edges being shared with additional pairs of
square-planar SeBr 4 units [4].
The dinuclear hexabromo-diselenate(II) anion was iso-
lated for first time as thetetraphenylphosphonium salt,
[PPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ], from the reaction of selenium tetrabromide,
SeBr 4 (which is in equilibrium with SeBr 2 , Se 2 Br 2 and Br 2
in solution), and tetraphenylphosphonium bromide,
[PPh 4 ]Br, [1]. The following sequence of reactions was pro-
posed for the formation of hexabromo-diselenate ions
SeBr 4 o SeBr 2 ϩ Br 2 ,
2SeBr 2 ϩ 2Br 2 ϩ 4[PPh 4 ]Br o [PPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] ϩ 2[PPh 4 ]Br 3 .
text.front:
* Prof. Dr. Vitalijus Janickis
Faculty of Chemical Technology
Kaunas University of Technology
Radvilenų str. 19, LT-50254 Kaunas, Lithuania
FAX: ϩ370 37 300152. PHONE: ϩ370 37 451464.
E-Mail: vitalijus.janickis@ktu.lt
Z. Anorg. Allg. Chem. 2008, 634, 901Ϫ904
© 2008 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
901
bromo-diselenate(II) anion is centrosymmetric and consists of two
distorted almost square-planar SeBr 4 units sharing a common edge
through two bridging Br atoms. The terminal Se II ϪBr bond dis-
tances are found to be 2.419(1) and 2.445(1) Å , the bridging
μBrϪSe II bond distances 2.901(1) and 2.802(1) Å .
Keywords: Selenium; Hexabromodiselenate(II); Crystal structure;
Tetraphenylphosphonium and Ethyltriphenylphosphonium ions
text.body:
Selenium reacts with bromine (1:1) in acetonitrile
solution:
2Se ϩ Br 2 o Se 2 Br 2 .
However when the Se/Br 2 ratio is 2.0, the formation of
Se 2 Br 2 is not quantitative [6, 7], since both Se 2 Br 2 and Br 2
participate in the disproportionation equilibria [6Ϫ8]:
2SeBr 2 o Se 2 Br 2 ϩ Br 2
and
3SeBr 2 o Se 2 Br 2 ϩ SeBr 4 .
Therefore, the selenium bromides SeBr 4 [8], Se 3 Br 2 and
Se 4 Br 2 , may be present in minor amounts in the reaction
mixture as well [6].
It had been shown earlier [2, 3, 6, 9, 13Ϫ11] that the
formation of species which will crystallize from the solution
when selenium reacts with bromine in the presence of bro-
mide ions, depends on equilibrium concentrations and solu-
bilities, respectively, and Ϫ especially Ϫ on the nature of
the cation, the bromide of which was used for the synthesis.
For example, the reaction of selenium with bromine
in the presence of phenyltrimethylammonium bromide,
[NMe 3 Ph]Br, was adapted [6] to the stoichiometry
5Se ϩ 4Br 2 ϩ 2Br Ϫ Ǟ [SeBr 6 (Se 2 Br 2 ) 2 ] 2Ϫ
and the first mixed-valence bromoselenate(IV/I), i.e. phenyl-
trimethylammonium hexabromoselenate(IV)-bis{dibromo-

diselenate(I)} [6], in which selenium is present in different
oxidation states, was isolated. If the same stoichiometry
for the interaction of selenium with bromine was used
but phenyltrimethylammonium bromide, [NMe 3 Ph]Br,
was replaced by tetraethylammonium bromide, [NEt 4 ]Br,
the first mixed-valence bromoselenate(II,I) containing
selenium in the oxidation states ϩ2 and ϩ1,
i.e. bis(tetraethylammonium) octabromo-triselenate(II)-
{dibromodiselenate(I)}, [NEt 4 ] 2 [Se 3 Br 8 (Se 2 Br 2 )], was ob-
tained in high yield [10].
In continuation of our earlier studies in the area of
halogenochalcogenates [2, 3, 6, 9Ϫ15], we have investigated
the reactions between elemental selenium and bromine in
acetonitrile solution in the presence of tetraphenylphos-
phonium bromide, [PPh 4 ]Br, and ethyltriphenylphos-
phonium bromide, [PEtPh 3 ]Br. We now report the new
direct synthesis of hexabromo-diselenate(II) compounds Ϫ
bis(tetraphenylphosphonium) and bis(ethyltriphenylphos-
phonium) hexabromo-diselenate(II), [PEtPh 3 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] and
[PPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ], respectively. We also report the crystal
structure of a new salt of the dinuclear bromoselenate(II)
anion, [PEtPh 3 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ].
Results and Discussion
As pointed out above, the reaction of selenium with bro-
mine in acetonitrile solution includes a number of equilibria

a Symmetry transformation: Ϫxϩ1/2,yϪ1/2,Ϫzϩ1/2; b Symmetry transfor-
mation: Ϫxϩ1/2,yϩ1/2,Ϫzϩ1/2
in which various selenium bromide species are involved, and
the nature of the cation the bromide of which is introduced
into the interacting Se/Br 2 system may have a significant
influence upon the composition of the bromochalcogenate
salt which crystallizes from the solution.
In an extensive experimental study the direct syntheses
of an earlier known bis(tetraphenylphosphonium) hexa-
bromo-diselenate(II), [PPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] (1) and of a new
bis(ethyltriphenylphosphonium) hexabromo-diselenate(II),
[PEtPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] (2), have been optimised. Under defined
experimental conditions the reactions between elemental
selenium and bromine, in the presence of the above Ϫ men-
tioned bromides (and excess of selenium), follow the equa-
tions
2Se ϩ 2Br 2 ϩ 2[PPh 4 ]Br Ǟ [PPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] (1)
2Se ϩ 2Br 2 ϩ 2[PEtPh 3 ]Br Ǟ [PEtPh 3 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] (2)
The tetraphenylphosphonium salt, [PPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] (1),
was isolated in about 90 % yield and ethyltriphenylphos-
phonium salt, [PEtPh 3 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] (2), Ϫ in about 85 % yield.
The compound 2 has been characterized by single-crystal
X-ray structure analysis. The crystal data, measurement
conditions, and results of the structure solution and refine-
ment are summarized in Table 1. The bond lengths and
angles of the anion in 2 are listed in Table 2.
The molecular structure of 2 is shown in Figure 1 and
the net-like association of the anions in the crystals of 2 Ϫ
formed by interionic Br•••Br contacts Ϫ in Figure 2.
The [Se 2 Br 6 ] 2Ϫ anion of 2 is centrosymmetric and con-
sists of two almost planar distorted SeBr 4 units sharing a
common edge through two bridging Br atoms, Br(3) and
Br(3A). The deviations of atoms from the least-squares
[SeBr 4 ] plane defined by Se, Br1, Br2, Br3, Br3a are in the
range of 0.0173(4)Ϫ0.0547(5) Å ). The atoms of the
[Se 2 Br 6 ] 2Ϫ anion are nearly in plane too: the deviations of
atoms from the least squares plane defined by Br1, Br2, Se,
Br3, Br3a, Sea, Br1a, Br2a are between 0.0065(3) and
0.0596(5) Å .
The [Se 2 Br 6 ] 2Ϫ anion of 2 may be compared with the
same centrosymmetric anion in [PPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] and asym-
metric anion of [NMe 3 Ph] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] [1, 3]. In the centrosym-
metric anion of 2 the asymmetry in the bonding system is
text.note: Direct Syntheses of [PPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] and [PEtPh 3 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ]
text.body:
Figure 1 Molecular structure of [PEtPh 3 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] (2). (The hydro-
gen atoms of the ethyl and phenyl groups are omitted for the sake
of clarity.)
more reduced, the two terminal bonds differing by 0.026 Å
and the two bridging bonds by 0.099 Å . The reason for this
asxmmetry,which occursin several dihalogeno-bridged chal-
cogen(II) and chalcogen(IV) compounds [1, 7, 16], is not
clear. In the case of [PPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] (1) where the asymmetr
is relatively large, it was pointed out, that it may be initiated
by interionic halogen-halogen contacts. But in 2, with even
smaller asymmetry than in [NMe 3 Ph] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ], all terminal
Br atoms (Br1 and Br2) have short interionic contacts,
3.606 Å . In the centrosymmetric anion of [PPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ]
(1) the bondsof the four-membered ring are alternatively
long and short; the same is observed in the centrosymmetric
anion of 2, whereas in the asymmetric anion of
[NMe 3 Ph] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] the longest bond is situated opposite to
the shortest one.
The selenium atoms of the [Se 2 Br 6 ] 2Ϫ anion of 2 are act-
ing as central atoms in the asymmetric, nearly linear sys-
tems Br1ϪSeϪBr3a and Br2ϪSeϪBr3. The angles at the
selenium atom are 175.12(4) and 174.45(4)°, respectively.
The Br terminal ϪSe II ϪBr terminal bond angle (94.72(4)°) is
larger than 90°, presumably due to an intramolecular
ligandϪligand interaction between the terminal Br atoms.
The bonds in the nearly linear Br t ϪSeϪμBr systems are
of the three-centre, four-electron (3cϪ4e) type with only
one occupied bonding orbital. All SeϪμBr bridging bonds
are considerably longer than the terminal SeϪBr bonds.
The average value of the total lengths of the linear
BrϪSeϪBr system in the [Se 2 Br 6 ] 2Ϫ ion of 2 is 5.2835 Å
which is close to the corresponding values in the [Se 2 Br 6 ] 2Ϫ
ion of [PPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] (1), 5.241 Å [1], and of
[NMe 3 Ph] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ], 5.270 Å [3].
In the directions of the SeϪBr1, SeϪBr2, SeaϪBr1a,
Se1aϪBr2a bonds of adjacent [Se 2 Br 6 ] 2Ϫ anions, the Br1
atoms have weak bonds to Br2 atoms and vice versa. These
intermolecular Br1•••Br2 distances are 3.6062(12) Å . As a
result, the net-like association of the anions in the crystals
of 2 is formed (Fig. 2).

Figure 2 The net-like association of the planar [Se 2 Br 6 ] 2Ϫ anions
in the crystals of 2, formed by interionic Br••••••Br contacts
The dimensions of the ethyltriphenylphosphonium
ion in 2 are within the expected ranges: PϪC ϭ
1.786(6)Ϫ1.807(6) Å ,
CϪC
ϭ
1.36(1)Ϫ1.53(1) Å ,
CϪPϪC
ϭ
106.2(3)Ϫ111.8(3)°,
PϪCϪC
ϭ
110.7(5)Ϫ123.1(5)°and CϪCϪC ϭ 118.8(6)Ϫ121.7(7)°;
they do not deviate from the usual values.
Experimental Section
Direct synthesis of [PPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] (1)
A suspension of 3.0 mmol (0.237 g) selenium (Aldrich) (an excess
of selenium Ϫ 3 mmol instead of 2 mmol) was used to prevent the
formation of Se IV containing particles) and 2.0 mmol (0.839 g) of
tetraphenylphosphonium bromide in 5 ml of acetonitrile was
treated with 2.0 mmol (0.32 g) of bromine. The mixture was stirred
and heated at 80°C for 30 min. Then 7 ml of acetonitrile were ad-
ded to the mixture, and the temperature was raised to 75°C. A
clear, dark brown solution was obtained, although small amounts
of selenium did not react. The reaction mixture was left for about
4 h at room temperature, and 1.09 g brown crystals of
[PPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] (1) were isolated. The filtrate was stored in a re-
frigerator (ϩ2°C) for 12 h, and 0.11 g more of the pure compound
1 were isolated. The total yield was 1.20 g (ϳ 90 %) as calculated
according to the amounts of the reagents used. Selenium was deter-
mined by treating a solution of the sample in acetonitrile with an
aqueous sulfite solution, adding bromide and oxidizing with bro-
mine. Excess of bromine was removed, and the amount of selenium
was determined iodometrically. Found: Se 12.47 %. Calculated for
[PPh 4 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] (1): Se 12.00 %. Determination of the unit cell di-
mensions confirmed that the crystals synthesized are of the com-
pound 1, earlier obtained by a different reaction [1].
The compound 1 forms dark brown, prism-like crystals which in
the presence of water gradually liberate red amorphous selenium.
Synthesis of [PEtPh 3 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] (2)
A suspension of 3.0 mmol (0.237 g) selenium (Aldrich) and
2.0 mmol (0.743 g) of ethyltriphenylphosphonium bromide in 5 ml
text.note: V. Janickis, M. Herberhold, W. Milius
text.body:
of acetonitrile was treated with 2.0 mmol (0.32 g) of bromine. The
mixture was stirred and heated at 78°C for 30 min. Then 15 ml of
acetonitrile were added to the mixture, and it was stirred and
heated at 78°C for 30 min more. A clear, dark brown solution was
obtained, although small amounts of selenium did not react. The
reaction mixture was left for about 4 h at room temperature, and
1.05 g brown crystals of [PEtPh 3 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ] (2) were isolated. The
yield was ϳ 85 %, as calculated according to the amounts of the
reagents used. Found: Se 13.47 %. Calculated for [PEtPh 3 ] 2 [Se 2 Br 6 ]
(2): Se 12.94 %.
The compound 2 forms dark brown, short prism-like crystals which
in the presence of water gradually liberate red amorphous selenium.
IR spectra (100Ϫ600 cm Ϫ1 ) were recorded on a spectrophotometer
Rekin-Elmer GX system FT-IR by averaging 64 scans with
0.3 cm Ϫ1 resolution at room temperature. The bands in the IR spec-
tra of hexabromo-diselenate(II) anion of compound 2 were found
at 246, 200, 148, 134, and 114 cm Ϫ1 . according to the literature data
[1, 17], the band at 114 cm Ϫ1 can be assigned to the asymmetric
deformation BrϪSeϪBr vibrations, δ as (BrϪSeϪBr), the bands at
134 and 148 cm Ϫ1 Ϫ to the symmetric deformation BrϪSeϪBr
vibrations, δ s (BrϪSeϪBr), and at 246 cm Ϫ1 Ϫ to the asymmetric
valence SeϪBr vibrations, ν as (SeϪBr).
X-ray structure analysis
The determination of the unit cell dimensions and the data collec-
tion were carried out on a STOE IPDS I diffractometer (graphite
monochromator). The structure was solved by direct methods and
refined by SHELXTL [18Ϫ20]. Atomic scattering factors were
taken from Tables 4.2.6.8 and 6.1.1.4 in ref. [21]. The crystal data
and the conditions for data collection and refinement are summar-
ised in Table 1. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined aniso-
tropically. The hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically and re-
fined using a riding model with isotropic thermal parameters equal
to 1.2 or 1.3 U(eq) for the phenyl and ethyl carbon atoms, respec-
tively, to which they are attached.
Complete lists of the final atomic coordinates, equivalent isotropic
displacement parameters, bond lengths and angles, anisotropic
temperature factors, structure factors, hydrogen coordinates and

least-squares planes have been deposited with the Cambridge Crys-
tallographic Data Centre under No CCDC-.
